utterances: I'm fine.
How are you?
I'm doing great.

So, you know, a lot of us, I think, frankly, almost all of us who are African-American, say, you know what, I need to, you know, each one teach one, lift somebody up, but when you're a judge, you have a very particular role, and it's a role where you are at somewhat of a remove, even though you're facing the defendants, you are not on the same level as them.
How do you make sense of what Judge Arrington did?
I understand what Judge Arrington did completely.
And I have to tell you why.
Though we must be removed, we are nonetheless human.
It is the easiest thing in the world to do, is to be removed if you don't care.
But if you have the nerve to care, and if you see what we see on a daily basis, his humanity and his caring came together that day and made him do something clearly he shouldn't have done.
He knows that.
But it was an error of the heart that I find fully condonable.
So, what other ways, you know, you say that you approve of the sentiment, not necessarily of the execution.
How else may he have gone about this?
I think he could have said it in front of the white attorneys.

In my courtroom, I, for a year and a half, wouldn't say anything directed towards a defendant that had anything to do with race because I felt it was inappropriate, but my second thought about it was, my job is to deal with this individual as best I can.
And if I feel that I can touch him, reach him, get to him, by mentioning, dealing with or encompassing race in the conversation, I have an obligation to do so.
And I can't worry about what white people are out there looking at me.
Because my job is with respect to him.
So, I say, say it!
You know, this issue hit home with you recently during the taping of your show, ""Divorce Court."" Tell us what happened.
What happened is I broke one of my mother's rules.
And my mother's rule is don't let your emotions straddle events.
I had come home, I had come to work, and my husband was in the emergency room when I called home.
One son was sick, and the other one wasn't going to school.
And I had my three wonderful men at home, I'm not taking (unintelligible) them.
And I got a third defendant there that day that was talking about how many babies he had with how many different black women.

Not with, not only not with a sense of shame, but with a sense of accomplishment, and with the backdrop of my great men that I live with and there are so many great brothers out there who I wasn't taking care of, and this guy, the third guy that day that took pride in that which he was doing that was damaging his women and me.
I took it personally.
I got upset.
I lost my composure.
And said something, and I said a whole lot of stuff, actually, and I wasn't sure what I said, and I made them play it back to me because I was afraid that I made have said something.
I might of had an Arrington moment.
(Soundbite of laughter)

And I hope not to brand the brother with that, because I love him, and I understand what he did, but I may have done, may have gone too far, and I wanted to have an opportunity, which is great, you can do it on t.v., but you can't do in real life, to review what you said in a moment of passion.
So, give me an example of what you said.
Not necessarily the language, but the meaning, the intent of what you said.
Is this it?
Is this all I get?
I took it personally, me to you, is this the best we can do as a people?
Is this the best you can do for me as a brother to a sister?
Are we going to live down to the expectations of those people who disdain us?
That was my message.
My language was quite different.
And I was afraid that my passion and my desire would get lost, got somehow lost in the, I don't know, the anger that I was feeling.
Now, there's also the toll, you know, that this takes on judges.
I mean, that's precisely what Judge Arrington said.
He said, seeing the same black faces walk in and out of his courtroom year after year takes its toll.
When you first became a judge in Cleveland Heights, Ohio, did you feel like it was something that you brought home with you, that you felt a weight on yourself?
Oh, no doubt about it.
I mean, I'm a control freak, and I'm goal oriented.
I took recidivism personally.
Every time I saw that same guy or that same woman come back in, it was a failure on my part.
And I did.
And it hurt me.
And I've cried.
I've made defendants cry.
I had the whole courtroom crying once because my sense of hurt was so real and so immediate.

Aren't we all glad that the potential bomb material wasn't in Ukraine anymore when the fighting started?
At the same time, Bunn says, there are still a lot of vulnerable stockpiles left.
Obama says terrorist groups, like the self-proclaimed Islamic State, are always on the lookout for new tools to wreak havoc.

In the run-up to this week's summit, a number of countries signed onto a treaty requiring them to handle nuclear material in a secure way.
But Kelsey Davenport of the Arms Control Association says because that treaty focuses on civilian material, it doesn't go far enough.
That's an area where the summit process could have done more.
There are huge stockpiles, particularly in the United States and Russia, of weapons usable nuclear material that are dedicated for military purposes.

But Tom Collina of the antinuclear Ploughshares Fund complains the Pentagon is still too invested in building nuclear weapons.

Collina and others say Obama deserves credit for curtailing Iran's nuclear program and for sounding the alarm about nuclear terrorism.
Now that the president has wrapped up his last security summit, Harvard's Bunn says there's a big question mark about what happens next.

The security summit is part of Obama's larger ambition of a world free of nuclear weapons.

One media organization single-handedly changed and reignited the debate over domestic violence and the NFL - TMZ.
On Monday the celebrity gossip site release security footage of running back Ray Rice knocking his then fiancee unconscious with a brutal punch.

Later that day the Baltimore Ravens cut Rice from the team and on Wednesday the NFL announced former FBI Director Robert Mueller would lead an investigation into how the organization handled the case.
It's not the first time TMZ and its outspoken founder, Harvey Levin, have triggered a national debate.
Anne Helen Petersen is a features writer for Buzzfeed and recently wrote an in-depth story about what makes TMZ tick.
Anne, welcome to the program.
Thank you.
And, Anne, as I just mentioned this is not the first time TMZ has scooped the rest of the news media like this.
Give us a quick rundown of TMZ's greatest hits.
They have basically scooped almost every single gossip and mainstream news organization on celebrity breaking news.

So everything from Michael Jackson's death, which they were the first to correctly report, to the footage of Solange Knowles attacking Jay Z just earlier this year, to the tapes of Donald Sterling that necessitated the sale of the Los Angeles Clippers.
Now how do they manage to get their hands on this type of material that, you know, a lot of people would like to get a hold of?

Harvey Levin has established a wide-ring of tipsters and has connections through many of his employees, relationships that funnel this information to him, but a lot of it is just that TMZ now is the place that people know to bring their information if they have something good.

Now Harvey Levin says that they don't pay for interviews, they don't pay very much for things like this and actually claim that they did not pay for this footage, but it seems very clear that that's not the case.
That it seems to be the case that they're paying for what they get?
Yes, that they're paying - he says that it's a small amount, but, you know, within the industry it seems clear that it's at least five figures, for especially this sort of very valuable videotape.

Now I have to say one thing I was kind of thrilled to read about in terms of their reporting practices is that TMZ puts money into good, old-fashioned investigative style, you know, reporting on the record, like with their court reporting.
Yes.
Well, and this is the thing that I think a lot of people are hesitant to admit.
They don't want to think of TMZ as investigative journalists in part because they don't heed some of the ethics that American journalism says are standard.

So the fact that they pay for stories, I mean, in Britain people pay for stories - that's been a long tradition within the journalism schools there - but here in America I would say that, you know, they employ people who haven't necessarily gone to journalism school, but who dig and who do that sort of nitty-gritty style journalism that in some ways isn't funded in a lot of organizations anymore.
Anne, you write about some of the precursors of TMV - the gossip magazines of the '50s in particular.
Is the TMZ empire today, the website and the show, are they doing anything really new?
I mean, they're using a lot of the tactics from the 1950s, but the real difference is digitization.
I mean, a scandal magazine came out, you know, once maybe twice a month, but TMZ reports a story and then offers constant updates on it.

And they also, you know, the information and the data that they use to indict these various celebrities almost all of it is - are materials that would not be possible to obtain without digital surveillance cameras and digital cameras in general and digital recording devices.
And we saw a really, you know, the unique power of video, you know, the scandal sheets never had that and that got TMZ into every single newscast.
Absolutely and I think that's really the power of this footage.
You know people like - we understand that domestic violence is a social ill, but it's easy to talk abstractly about it and you see this video and you can't ignore it.
